lines.text: Enter MENENIUS with the two Tribunes of the people, SICINIUS and BRUTUS.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: The augurer tells me we shall have news tonight.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Good or bad

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Not according to the prayer of the people, for they love not Marcius.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Pray you, who does the wolf love

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: The lamb.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Ay, to devour him as the hungry plebeians would the noble Marcius.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Hes a lamb indeed, that baes like a bear.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Hes a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb. You two are old men: tell me one thing that I shall ask you.

lines.speaker: both
lines.text: Well, sir.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: In what enormity is Marcius poor in, that you two have not in abundance

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Hes poor in no one fault, but stored with all.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Especially in pride.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: And topping all others in boasting.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: This is strange now: do you two know how you are censured here in the city, I mean of us o the righthand file do you

lines.speaker: both
lines.text: Why, how are we censured

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Because you talk of pride now,will you not be angry

lines.speaker: both
lines.text: Well, well, sir, well.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Why, tis no great matter for a very little thief of occasion will rob you of a great deal of patience: give your dispositions the reins, and be angry at your pleasures at the least if you take it as a pleasure to you in being so. You blame Marcius for being proud

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: We do it not alone, sir.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: I know you can do very little alone for your helps are many, or else your actions would grow wondrous single: your abilities are too infantlike for doing much alone. You talk of pride: O that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks, and make but an interior survey of your good selves! O that you could!

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: What then, sir

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, proud, violent, testy magistrates, alias fools, as any in Rome.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Menenius, you are known well enough too.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one that loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying Tiber int said to be something imperfect in favouring the first complaint hasty and tinderlike upon too trivial motion one that converses more with the buttock of the night than with the forehead of the morning: what I think I utter, and spend my malice in my breath. Meeting two such wealsmen as you areI cannot call you Lycurgusesif the drink you give me touch my palate adversely, I make a crooked face at it. I cant say your worships have delivered the matter well, when I find the ass in compound with the major part of your syllables: and though I must be content to bear with those that say you are reverend grave men, yet they lie deadly that tell you you have good faces. If you see this in the map of my microcosm, follows it that I am known well enough too what barm can your bisson conspectuities glean out of this character, if I be known well enough too

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: You know neither me, yourselves nor any thing. You are ambitious for poor knaves caps and legs: you wear out a good wholesome forenoon in hearing a cause between an orange wife and a fossetseller and then rejourn the controversy of three pence to a second day of audience. When you are hearing a matter between party and party, if you chance to be pinched with the colic, you make faces like mummers set up the bloody flag against all patience and, in roaring for a chamberpot, dismiss the controversy bleeding the more entangled by your hearing: all the peace you make in their cause is, calling both the parties knaves. You are a pair of strange ones.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Come, come, you are well understood to be a perfecter giber for the table than a necessary bencher in the Capitol.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Our very priests must become mockers, if they shall encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are. When you speak best unto the purpose, it is not worth the wagging of your beards and your beards deserve not so honourable a grave as to stuff a botchers cushion, or to be entombed in an asss pack saddle. Yet you must be saying, Marcius is proud who in a cheap estimation, is worth predecessors since Deucalion, though peradventure some of the best of em were hereditary hangmen. Godden to your worships: more of your conversation would infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly plebeians: I will be bold to take my leave of you. How now, my as fair as noble ladies,and the moon, were she earthly, no nobler,whither do you follow your eyes so fast
BRUTUS and SICINIUS go aside
Enter VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA, and VALERIA

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: Honourable Menenius, my boy Marcius approaches for the love of Juno, lets go.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Ha! Marcius coming home!

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: Ay, worthy Menenius and with most prosperous approbation.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Take my cap, Jupiter, and I thank thee. Hoo! Marcius coming home!

lines.speaker: virgilia
lines.text: Nay,tis true.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: Look, heres a letter from him: the state hath another, his wife another and, I think, theres one at home for you.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: I will make my very house reel tonight: a letter for me!

lines.speaker: virgilia
lines.text: Yes, certain, theres a letter for you I sawt.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: A letter for me! it gives me an estate of seven years health in which time I will make a lip at the physician: the most sovereign prescription in Galen is but empiricutic, and, to this preservative, of no better report than a horsedrench. Is he not wounded he was wont to come home wounded.

lines.speaker: virgilia
lines.text: O, no, no, no.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: O, he is wounded I thank the gods fort.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: So do I too, if it be not too much: brings a victory in his pocket the wounds become him.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: Ons brows: Menenius, he comes the third time home with the oaken garland.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: Titus Lartius writes, they fought together, but Aufidius got off.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: And twas time for him too, Ill warrant him that: an he had stayed by him, I would not have been so fidiused for all the chests in Corioli, and the gold thats in them. Is the senate possessed of this

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: Good ladies, lets go. Yes, yes, yes the senate has letters from the general, wherein he gives my son the whole name of the war: he hath in this action outdone his former deeds doubly

lines.speaker: valeria
lines.text: In troth, theres wondrous things spoke of him.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Wondrous! ay, I warrant you, and not without his true purchasing.

lines.speaker: virgilia
lines.text: The gods grant them true!

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: True! pow, wow.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: True! Ill be sworn they are true. Where is he wounded God save your good worships! Marcius is coming home: he has more cause to be proud. Where is he wounded
To the Tribunes

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: I the shoulder and i the left arm there will be large cicatrices to show the people, when he shall stand for his place. He received in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts i the body.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: One i the neck, and two i the thigh,theres nine that I know.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: He had, before this last expedition, twentyfive wounds upon him.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Now its twentyseven: every gash was an enemys grave. Hark! the trumpets.
A shout and flourish

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: These are the ushers of Marcius: before him he carries noise, and behind him he leaves tears: Death, that dark spirit, in s nervy arm doth lie Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die. A sennet. Trumpets sound. Enter COMINIUS the  general, and TITUS LARTIUS between them, CORIOLANUS,  crowned with an oaken garland with Captains and Soldiers, and a Herald

lines.speaker: herald
lines.text: Know, Rome, that all alone Marcius did fight Within Corioli gates: where he hath won, With fame, a name to Caius Marcius these In honour follows Coriolanus. Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!
Flourish

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: No more of this it does offend my heart: Pray now, no more.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Look, sir, your mother!

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: O, You have, I know, petitiond all the gods For my prosperity!
Kneels

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: Nay, my good soldier, up My gentle Marcius, worthy Caius, and By deedachieving honour newly named, What is itCoriolanus must I call thee But O, thy wife!

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: My gracious silence, hail! Wouldst thou have laughd had I come coffind home, That weepst to see me triumph Ay, my dear, Such eyes the widows in Corioli wear, And mothers that lack sons.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Now, the gods crown thee!

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: And live you yet O my sweet lady, pardon.
To VALERIA

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: I know not where to turn: O, welcome home: And welcome, general: and yere welcome all.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: A hundred thousand welcomes. I could weep And I could laugh, I am light and heavy. Welcome. A curse begin at very root ons heart, That is not glad to see thee! You are three That Rome should dote on: yet, by the faith of men, We have some old crabtrees here at home that will not Be grafted to your relish. Yet welcome, warriors: We call a nettle but a nettle and The faults of fools but folly.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Ever right.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Menenius ever, ever.

lines.speaker: herald
lines.text: Give way there, and go on!

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: [To VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA]  Your hand, and yours: Ere in our own house I do shade my head, The good patricians must be visited From whom I have received not only greetings, But with them change of honours.

lines.speaker: volumnia
lines.text: I have lived To see inherited my very wishes And the buildings of my fancy: only Theres one thing wanting, which I doubt not but Our Rome will cast upon thee.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Know, good mother, I had rather be their servant in my way, Than sway with them in theirs.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: On, to the Capitol!
Flourish. Cornets. Exeunt in state, as before. BRUTUS and SICINIUS come forward

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights Are spectacled to see him: your prattling nurse Into a rapture lets her baby cry While she chats him: the kitchen malkin pins Her richest lockram bout her reechy neck, Clambering the walls to eye him: stalls, bulks, windows, Are smotherd up, leads filld, and ridges horsed With variable complexions, all agreeing In earnestness to see him: seldshown flamens Do press among the popular throngs and puff To win a vulgar station: or veild dames Commit the war of white and damask in Their nicelygawded cheeks to the wanton spoil Of Phoebus burning kisses: such a pother As if that whatsoever god who leads him Were slily crept into his human powers And gave him graceful posture.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: On the sudden, I warrant him consul.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Then our office may, During his power, go sleep.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: He cannot temperately transport his honours From where he should begin and end, but will Lose those he hath won.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: In that theres comfort.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Doubt not The commoners, for whom we stand, but they Upon their ancient malice will forget With the least cause these his new honours, which That he will give them make I as little question As he is proud to dot.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: I heard him swear, Were he to stand for consul, never would he Appear i the marketplace nor on him put The napless vesture of humility Nor showing, as the manner is, his wounds To the people, beg their stinking breaths.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Tis right.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: It was his word: O, he would miss it rather Than carry it but by the suit of the gentry to him, And the desire of the nobles.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: I wish no better Than have him hold that purpose and to put it In execution.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Tis most like he will.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: It shall be to him then as our good wills, A sure destruction.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: So it must fall out To him or our authorities. For an end, We must suggest the people in what hatred He still hath held them that tos power he would Have made them mules, silenced their pleaders and Dispropertied their freedoms, holding them, In human action and capacity, Of no more soul nor fitness for the world Than camels in the war, who have their provand Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows For sinking under them.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: This, as you say, suggested At some time when his soaring insolence Shall touch the peoplewhich time shall not want, If he be put upon t and thats as easy As to set dogs on sheepwill be his fire To kindle their dry stubble and their blaze Shall darken him for ever.
Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Whats the matter

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: You are sent for to the Capitol. Tis thought That Marcius shall be consul: I have seen the dumb men throng to see him and The blind to bear him speak: matrons flung gloves, Ladies and maids their scarfs and handkerchers, Upon him as he passd: the nobles bended, As to Joves statue, and the commons made A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts: I never saw the like.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Lets to the Capitol And carry with us ears and eyes for the time, But hearts for the event.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Have with you.
Exeunt
